Overview 

The process to create an applet or an application using grins package is as follows:

1. SMIL documents

To start using the grins package you have to supply the license given to you. You do this by calling the setLicense() static method of GRiNSToolkit passing as argument the license string.

grins.GRiNSToolkit.setLicense(licenseStr);

After you have set the license you are ready to create a SMIL document using the createDocument() factory method of a GRiNSToolkit:

            SMILDocument smil = null;

           try    { smil = grins.GRiNSToolkit.createDocument(filenameOrUrl); }

catch(GRiNSException e) {smil = null; System.out.println(""+e);}

From an instance of a SMILDocument object you can get all the necessary info to prepare things for document playback.

For example you can request document's duration with the call

double dur = smil.getDuration();

But be careful. Check for a negative or zero return value. A dur = 0 means that document's duration its indefinite and a dur<0 means its unresolved.

You request  the number of top-level windows of the document with the call

int viewportsCount = smil.getViewportCount();

You can omit this call if you are working with SMIL documents having one toplevel window.

 Top-level windows are assigned an index.

You get top-level window's size associated with index 0 with the call

Dimension d = smil.getViewportSize(0);

and its title with the call

String title = smil.getViewportTitle(0)

For document playback you have to create a SMILCanvas object for each SMIL top-level window . 

SMILCanvas canvas = new grins.SMILCanvas();

and set its dimensions to the that returned by smil.getViewportSize(). A SMILCanvas is a java.awt.Canvas implementing  java.awt.event.MouseListener and java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener interfaces. It further overrides the paint() method. But its still a  java.awt.Canvas and you can use it as such in your application. 

SMIL canvases are associated to SMIL top-level windows with the following code fragment

try {smil.getRenderer().setCanvas(0, canvas);}

catch(GRiNSException e){System.out.println(""+e);}

 

2. Playback

To control playback you need a SMILController. You request a smil controller from the document object

SMILController player = smil.getController()

To receive playback notifications you have to register a class implementing the SMILListener interface

player.addListener(listenerObject);

See the api documentation for the interface a SMILListener object should implement.

You can then call play/pause/stop against the instance of a SMILController

player.play();

...

player.pause();

player.play();

...

player.stop()

 

3. Cleanup

And finally, you close the document to release the associated resources

smil.close();

Please see the demos for more details.
